overview: Your employment contract - how it can be changed, problems with changes and breach of contract
title: Your employment contract:  how it can be changed

table.body:
Usually, you and your employer must agree for a contract to be changed. 

If you want to make a change, speak to your employer and explain why. You can't insist on making changes unless they're covered by a statutory right (eg not working on a Sunday). 

If your employer wants to make changes, they should

- consult or negotiate with you or your representative (eg from a trade union or staff association)
- explain the reasons why
- listen to alternative ideas you may have
table.title: Consultation

table.body:
If your employer changes any terms in your [written statement](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/written-statement-of-employment-particulars "Written statement of employment particulars") with your agreement, they must confirm the change in writing within a month. You must be told exactly what has changed in the statement. 

If your employer changes terms and conditions that aren't in the [written statement](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/written-statement-of-employment-particulars "Written statement of employment particulars") (eg like the right to sick leave), they should tell you where to find information about the change (eg a company handbook, noticeboard or intranet site).  

##Collective agreements and changes to written statements
A [collective agreement](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/collective-agreements "Collective agreements") may exist between your employer and trade unions or a staff association. If your employer makes agreed changes to the terms of the collective agreement, they should inform you in writing.

Negotiations under a collective agreement can lead to changes in the terms of your [written statement](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/written-statement-of-employment-particulars "Written statement of employment particulars") (eg pay or working hours).  If you are covered by a collective agreement, any changes will apply to you whether you are a member of a union or staff association or not.

##Flexibility clauses 
Flexibility clauses are terms in your contract that give your employer the right to change some of your terms and conditions. A flexibility clause could be that your job location can be changed. 

Your employer isn't allowed to make completely unreasonable changes using a flexibility clause. 

$E **Example** telling you to move to another country to work at 1 day's notice would be completely unreasonable. $E

##Changes of employer
If your employer changes, usually you must be given a new [written statement of particulars](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/written-statement-of-employment-particulars "Written statement of employment particulars") within 2 months.

However, if the name of the business changes or there's a [new employer](/business-transfers-and-takeovers-your-rights/overview "Business transfers and takeovers - your rights") but no other changes in terms and conditions, your employer doesn't need to issue a new written statement. However, they should inform you in writing of the changes within a month.

##Disciplinary measures 
Sometimes changes to your terms and conditions like a demotion can happen as a result of a disciplinary measure. 

Your employer should make sure the staff handbook or intranet site contains information about how this could happen in the section dealing with disciplinary procedures.
table.title: Types of change

table.body:
Problems can arise if: 

- an employer tries to change your contract without agreement or re-employs you on new terms and conditions
- there is a breach of contract where one of the terms in a contract is broken (eg an employer doesn't pay agreed wages or employees don't work agreed hours)

##Talk to your employer
If you have a problem over contract changes, try to [solve](/solve-workplace-dispute/overview "Solve a workplace dispute") things informally by talking to your employer or through [mediation.](/solve-workplace-dispute/mediation-conciliation-and-arbitration "Mediation, conciliation and arbitration")

You can also get advice from your trade union representative (if you're a member of a union), [Citizen's Advice](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/ "Citizen's Advice"){:rel="external"} or ACAS. If you live in Northern Ireland you can also get advice from Labour Relations Agency (LRA) .

$C
**ACAS helpline**  
08457 47 47 47  
Monday to Friday 8am to 8pm, Saturday 9am to 1pm
$C

$C
**LRA helpline**  
028 9032 1442  
Monday to Friday 9am to 5pm  
$C

##Legal action
If the problem can't be solved, you may have the right to take legal action. Get advice before you do - legal action can be expensive. If you're a trade union member, you may be able to get legal advice from your union.  

##Making a change without agreement
If your employer makes a change to contracts without your agreement (including by using flexibility clauses unreasonably), you may:

- have the right to refuse to work the new conditions 
- say you are working any new terms under protest and you're treating the change as a breach of contract
- resign and claim [constructive dismissal](/dismissal/unfair-and-constructive-dismissal "Unfair and constructive dismissal")
- be able to take a case to an [employment tribunal](/employment-tribunals/taking-a-case-to-an-employment-tribunal "Employment tribunals") 

^In Northern Ireland you would take your case to an industrial tribunal.^

###Working new terms and conditions
If you disagree with new terms and conditions but don't say or do anything, this may count as agreeing to the changes. 

##Re-employment on new terms and conditions
Employers may, as a last resort, end your contract and re-employ you on new terms and conditions. 

Employers who are dismissing employees must follow the legally required:

* [redundancy procedure](/redundant-your-rights/20-or-more-redundancies "20 or more redundancies") in England, Wales and Scotland
* statutory minimum dismissal in Northern Ireland

If your employer does dismiss and re-employ you, you may be able to take a case to a tribunal and claim:

- breach of contract
- [unfair dismissal](/dismissal/unfair-and-constructive-dismissal "Unfair and constructive dismissal")

##Breach of contract claims
If you can't solve things informally with your employer, you may be able to take a breach of contract case to a civil court, an [employment tribunal](/employment-tribunals/taking-a-case-to-an-employment-tribunal "Employment tribunals"). If you live in Northern Ireland you can take your case to an industrial tribunal.

If you go to a tribunal, your employer may be able to make a counter-claim. 

Claims and counter-claims can only go to a tribunal if they:

- are related to an employment contract issue
- still haven't been solved when the employee ends their employment with your company

Also, the claim or counter-claim mustn't be related to a personal injury or things like a contract term that deals with [intellectual property rights.](/intellectual-property-an-overview/what-is-intellectual-property "What is intellectual property") 

###Time limits
Usually, you must make a claim to a tribunal within 3 months of ending your employment at the company. Your employer must make a counter-claim within 6 weeks of receiving a copy of your claim. 

###Compensation limits
If a tribunal agrees with your claim, they may award you compensation. You can only get compensation for financial loss (eg non-payment of wages) in breach of contract claim. The maximum compensation that can be given is £25,000.


*[LRA]: Labour Relations Agency
*[ACAS]: Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service
table.title: Problems with changes
